title: 114_hr4894
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. REPEAL OF LIQUIDATION AUTHORITY." is a concise summary of the content. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is repealed, and any laws amended by it will be effective as if the Act had not been enacted. Amendments are made to the Act, including changes to the definition of a financial company. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is repealed, and any laws amended by it will be effective as if the Act had not been enacted. Amendments are made to the Act, including changes to the definition of a financial company, which includes various types of companies such as bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is repealed, and any laws amended by it will be effective as if the Act had not been enacted. Amendments are made to the Act, including changes to the definition of a financial company, which includes various types of companies such as bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors. Any subsidiary predominantly engaged in financial activities as determined by the Board of Governors under the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is also included in the definition. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is repealed, with amendments made to the Act, including changes to the definition of a financial company. This definition encompasses various entities like bank holding companies, nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors, insured depository institutions, and insurance companies. Amendments are also made to specific sections within the Act, removing references to receivers appointed under title II and covered financial companies under title II. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to include changes to the definition of a financial company, encompassing entities like bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors. Amendments are made to specific sections within the Act, including provisions related to bankruptcy filings and public debt transactions. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to include changes to the definition of financial companies, such as bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors. Amendments are made to specific sections within the Act, including provisions related to bankruptcy filings and public debt transactions. The Federal Reserve Act is also amended to implement authority for orderly liquidation of such companies under title II of the Financial Stability Act of 2010. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to include changes to the definition of financial companies, such as bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies supervised by the Board of Governors. Amendments are made to specific sections within the Act, including provisions related to bankruptcy filings and public debt transactions. Additionally, amendments are made to allow for orderly liquidation of such companies under title II of the Financial Stability Act of 2010.
